Mesostructured carbon nitride synthesized by NaOH-assisted detemplation for enhanced catalytic synthesis of dimethyl carbonate from ethylene carbonate Xue-Wen Zhang Writing – original draft Investigation Jing-Yun Xu Validation Formal analysis Zhou-Hong Yu Investigation Data curation Fei Wang Validation Jie Xu Writing – review & editing Conceptualization ⁎ 1 Bing Xue Supervision ⁎ 2 Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Gehu Middle Road 21, Changzhou, Jiangsu 213164, PR China Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University Gehu Middle Road 21 Changzhou Jiangsu 213164 PR China Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Gehu Middle Road 21, Changzhou, Jiangsu 213164, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 ORCID: 0000-0002-2413-8405 2 ORCID: 0000-0001-6740-4665 Dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is an important building block in modern chemical synthesis, and the transesterification reaction between ethylene carbonate (EC) and CH3OH has been widely regarded as one of the most promising routes for the synthesis of DMC. Herein, a series of mesoporous carbon nitride (mpg-C3N4-x) materials were synthesized through a hard-templating method, adopting NaOH (a.q.) as a facile detemplating agent. Compared with the mpg-C3N4-F material prepared using traditional corrosive NH4HF2 (a.q.) as the detemplating agent, the mpg-C3N4-x materials possessed higher percentages of active bridging nitrogen species. Under optimal reaction conditions, the conversion of EC and selectivity to DMC achieved in mpg-C3N4 were up to 81.2 % and 99.9 %. The utilization of NaOH (a.q.) could alter the distributions of nitrogen species and enhance the alkaline strength of mpg-C3N4. As metal-free heterogeneous catalysts, the mpg-C3N4-x materials showed good recyclability and versatility for the transesterification reactions of various substrates. Graphical Abstract Keywords Carbon nitride Metal-free catalysis Base catalyst Transesterification Dimethyl carbonate Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Because of low toxicity, excellent biodegradability, and high versatility, dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is extensively used in numerous fields [1,2], including lithium-battery electrolytes, fuel additives, and building blocks for the synthesis of polycarbonates, etc [3]. In addition, DMC is regarded as an ideal substitute for highly toxic phosgene and dimethyl sulfate in carbonylation and methylation reactions, respectively [4,5]. With the increasing requirement for green synthesis and wide application of lithium batteries, efficient and clean production of DMC has become a hot research topic in the fields of both organic synthesis and green chemistry. Traditionally, the industrial synthetic approach of DMC is the phosgene process, which is being phased out due to its severe corrosivity and toxicity [6]. The oxidative carbonylation of methanol also suffers from a low selectivity to DMC. As for the alcoholysis of urea and the reaction between CO2 and methanol, the productivity of DMC in these processes is relatively low [7,8]. By contrast, the transesterification reaction between cyclic carbonates (represented by ethylene carbonate, EC) and low alcohols (e.g. CH3OH) has been widely regarded as one of the most promising routes for the synthesis of DMC as such a process does not involve hazardous raw materials and can be also operated under mild reaction conditions [1,8]. The most active catalysts reported for the transesterification of cyclic carbonates and CH3OH are sodium methoxide and alkali metal compounds [9,10]. Despite their high activity, the two catalysts are homogeneous, confronting difficulties in product separation and catalyst recovery. Furthermore, the metal ions in the catalysts are liable to metal contamination to DMC [11,12], thus limiting its wide application. In this context, it is of interest to explore a metal-free and robust catalyst for the clean production of DMC. The past decades have witnessed the wide application of graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) in a variety of research fields [13,14]. As for heterogeneous catalysis, owning to rich nitrogen species, g-C3N4 is a typical solid base and can promote transesterification reactions [10,15,16] and other base-mediated organocatalysis [17,18]. Compared with bulk g-C3N4 prepared by direct thermal condensation, mesoporous g-C3N4 materials possess large surface areas and accessible mesopores [16,19], thereby improving the catalytic activity in the above catalytic reactions. Nevertheless, it should be pointed out that, most mesoporous g-C3N4 materials are prepared through hard-templating methods that employ HF or NH4HF2 (a.q.) to etch silica templates. Such detemplating agents are very corrosive and more importantly, the acidic solution could inevitably damage the original alkaline active sites of g-C3N4 [20], thus restricting the overall catalytic activity. To circumvent this problem, Su et al. [21] prepared mpg-C3N4 by a hard-templating method and then treated it with NaOH (a.q.). The alkaline post-treatment was found to essentially conduct deprotonation of mpg-C3N4 and finally enhanced the catalytic activity in Knoevenagel condensation reactions. Notwithstanding, the post-treatment is relatively complicated and the influences of deprotonation of mpg-C3N4 on the alkaline strength and catalytic activity remained not fully explained. In this work, a series of mpg-C3N4 materials were synthesized through a hard-templating method, adopting NaOH (a.q.) as a facile detemplating agent, more eco-benign than the traditional but corrosive etching agent (i.e. HF or NH4HF2 (a.q.)). The characterization result exhibited that NaOH could not only eliminate the silica template but also alter the distributions of nitrogen species in mpg-C3N4. Compared with the mpg-C3N4-F material prepared using traditional NH4HF2 (a.q.) as the detemplating agent, the mpg-C3N4-x materials possessed higher fractions of active bridging nitrogen species. As the reaction temperature and time were 140 °C and 2 h, the yield of DMC achieved in mpg-C3N4-0.3 was up to 81.2 %, along with high selectivity (99.9 %) to DMC. Furthermore, the metal-free mpg-C3N4 catalysts can promote transesterification reactions of various cyclic carbonates and low alcohols and also can be recycled at least four times without a significant decrease in activity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Colloidal silica nanoparticle dispersion (Ludox® HS40, 40 wt%, mean size of silica nanoparticles is ca.12 nm, Sigma–Aldrich), cyanamide (99 %, Sigma–Aldrich), NaOH (A.R., Sinopharm Chemical), NH4HF2 (A.R., Sinopharm Chemical), dicyandiamide (C.P., Sinopharm Chemical), ethanol (A.R., Sinopharm Chemical), methanol (A.R. Sinopharm Chemical), EC (>99.0 %, Sinopharm Chemical), and N2 (99.999 %, Changzhou Huayang Gas Co. Ltd.) were used as received without further purification. The water used in the material preparation was made through reverse osmosis, and the resistivity of the water was higher than 15 MΩ·cm. 2.2 Material preparation 2.2.1 Mesostructured g-C3N4 Mesostructured g-C3N4 materials were prepared according to the previous silica-templating approach reported by Goettmann et al. [22]. In brief, 4 g of cyanamide was added into 12 g of colloidal silica nanoparticle dispersion and then stirred for 2 h, and then ultrasonicated for 20 min. The mixture was heated under 60 °C for at least 4 h until complete drying. Afterwards, the white solid was ground, transferred into a crucible with a lid, heated with a ramping slope of 3 °C·min−1 to reach a final temperature of 550 °C, and then temperated for this temperature for another 3 h. The obtained pale yellow powder was labeled as mpg-C3N4-SiO2. Mpg-C3N4-SiO2 was added into 400 mL of NaOH aqueous solution with a molar concentration of x mol·L−1 (x = 0.2, 0.3, or 0.4), and the mixture was stirred under reflux at 60 °C for 6 h. Afterward, the mixture was filtrated and rinsed with water (200 mL for each time) at least three times until the pH value of the filtrate was ca. 7. The filtrated yellow solid was rinsed with ethanol (100 mL) and then dried at 80 °C for 6 h. The resultant yellow powder was designated as mpg-C3N4-x, where x represented the molar concentration of NaOH (a.q.). Unless otherwise specified, x was 0.3. For comparison, NH4HF2 (a.q.) was also used as a detemplation agent to prepare mesostructured g-C3N4. Like the preparation of mpg-C3N4-x, mpg-C3N4-SiO2 was added into 200 mL of NH4HF2 aqueous solution (4 mol·L−1) and then stirred at room temperature for 24 h. After that, the mixture was filtrated and rinsed with water and ethanol like the corresponding preparation steps of mpg-C3N4-x. The resultant powder was named as mpg-C3N4-F. 2.2.2 Bulk g-C3N4 The bulk g-C3N4 was prepared through a simple thermal condensation. Briefly, 4 g of dicyandiamide was placed into a crucible with a lid, heated with a ramping rate of 3 °C·min−1 to reach a final temperature of 550 °C, and then temperated for this temperature for another 3 h. For comparison, the g-C3N4 material was also treated by NaOH (0.3 mol·L−1, a.q.) like the preparation of mpg-C3N4-x. The obtained NaOH-treated g-C3N4 was labeled as g-C3N4-0.3. 2.3 Material characterization The physicochemical properties of the materials were characterized by N2 adsorption–desorption technique, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transforms infrared (FT-IR), UVvis diffuse reflectance spectra, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD), and thermogravimetry (TG) analysis. The alkaline distributions of the materials were determined by Hammett titration using neutral red (pK a = 7.4), phenolphthalein (9.4), and thymolphthalein (10.0) as indicators. The information on apparatuses and detailed analytic methods are provided in the supporting information. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation Transesterification reactions of EC with CH3OH were performed in an autoclave (ca. 25 mL). EC (25 mmol) and CH3OH (250 mmol) were mixed well and added into the reactor, followed by the addition of 100 mg of the catalyst. The autoclave was charged with N2 up to ca. 0.7 MPa (The gas pressure was to keep the state of the reagents in a liquid state; the pressures under room temperature before and after the reaction almost did not alter while the maximum pressure within the reaction under heating was ca. 1.1 MPa.), and then heated at 140 °C for 2 h under stirring (300 rpm). After the completion of the reaction, the autoclave was cooled immediately in ice water and then exhausted slowly. The liquid-phase mixture was separated by centrifugation and analyzed by a gas chromatograph equipped with an FFAP capillary column and FID. The carbon balance was 100 ± 2 %. Considering that the stoichiometric ratio of EC is lower than CH3OH in this reaction, the catalytic conversion was calculated based on EC. The detailed EC conversion and selectivity to the target molecule (DMC) were calculated based on an area-normalization method of GC, and the corresponding calculation equations are as follows: C o n v . = A DMC × f DMC + A HEMC × f HEMC A EC × f EC + A DMC × f DMC + A HEMC × f HEMC ⁢ S e l . = A DMC × f DMC A HEMC × f HEMC + A DMC × f DMC where A and f were the peak area and response factor (based on EC), respectively, for each component analyzed by GC. It is noted that the byproduct (2-hydroxyethyl methyl carbonate, HEMC) was hard to detect in the GC diagram. Therefore, the selectivities to DMC were nearly 99.9 %. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Material characterization Fig. 1 shows XRD patterns of g-C3N4 and mpg-C3N4-x materials. The XRD pattern of g-C3N4 showed two distinct characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ = 27.5 ° and 12.7 °, indexed as the interlayer stacking (i.e. (002) plane) and the intralayer stacking (i.e. (100) plane) of the graphitic structure, respectively. Likewise, mpg-C3N4-F and mpg-C3N4-x materials prepared by the hard-templating method possessed graphitic structures. Compared with the bulk g-C3N4 that was prepared via direct thermal condensation, the intensities of both (002) and (100) planes were weakened in the cases of mpg-C3N4-F and mpg-C3N4-x materials. The decline in peak intensity, also discovered by other previous work involving mesoporous g-C3N4 materials [17,19,23], probably resulted from the partial collapse of the graphitic structure during the silica-etching procedure. On the other hand, compared with g-C3N4 and mpg-C3N4-F, the g-C3N4-0.3 and mpg-C3N4-0.3 treated with NaOH (a.q.) exhibited no significant changes in either diffraction intensity or peak position, suggesting that treatment of NaOH had no remarkable influence in the degree of crystallinity of g-C3N4 and mpg-C3N4. The N2 adsorption–desorption isothermal curves and pore size distributions of various materials are described in Fig. 2. The curves of g-C3N4 and g-C3N4-0.3 materials revealed no apparent adsorption of N2, indicative of poor porous structures in the two materials. By contrast, mpg-C3N4-F showed typical type-IV isothermal curves along with an H3 hysteretic loop at p/p 0= 0.6 −0.9, suggesting that the materials contained mesoporous structures. The mpg-C3N4-x materials also demonstrated type IV curves; however, showing H1-type hysteretic loops in the range of p/p 0= 0.4 −0.8. The corresponding pore size distributions are displayed in Fig. 2B. The pore size of mpg-C3N4-F was concentrated at ca. 12 nm, consistent with the average particle size of the silica template (the mean size of colloid silica nanoparticles, i.e. Ludox HS 40 is ca. 12 nm), suggesting that the mesopores of mpg-C3N4-F essentially originated from the negative replica of silica nanoparticles. As for mpg-C3N4-x, the pore sizes were ca. 7 nm, much less than the value of mpg-C3N4. In view of the hard-templating approach, the use of NaOH (a.q.) resembled NH4HF2 (a.q.), the function of which was to eliminate the silica template by chemical reactions. Nevertheless, besides detemplation, NaOH (a.q.) could also react with some nitrogen-containing species of g-C3N4 (discussed below), thereby altering the nitrogen distributions and even the porous structures thereof. Table 1 lists the specific surface areas, and pore information of the materials. Both g-C3N4 and g-C3N4-0.3 had very low specific surface areas (< 12 m2·g−1). In contrast, the mpg-C3N4-F had a higher specific surface area (216 m2·g−1) and pore volume (0.75 cm3·g−1). In comparison, the mpg-C3N4-x materials had inferior surface areas and pore volumes to mpg-C3N4-F. As the concentration of NaOH (a.q.) was increased, the surface areas as well as pore sizes of mpg-C3N4-x decreased gradually, pointing out the partial collapse of mesoporous structures of mpg-C3N4 during the detemplating procedure by NaOH. In this work, because either g-C3N4 or mpg-C3N4 was essentially synthesized through a thermal condensation method adopting dicyandiamide /cyanamide as a precursor, the g-C3N4 or mpg-C3N4 material inevitably contained a certain amount of oligomeric nitrogen-containing species (such heptazine [24]). Such nitrogen-containing species would react with NaOH (a.q.) thus transforming to small ammonia molecules. Due to the decomposition of these oligomeric nitrogen-containing species, the mesostructures of mpg-C3N4 suffered partial destruction or collapse. Consequently, the overall surface areas and pore volumes of mpg-C3N4-x materials were much lower than those of mpg-C3N4-F. Especially in the presence of a higher concentration of NaOH (a.q.), the decline in textural properties because of destruction by NaOH would become more pronounced. The thermal stability of the g-C3N4 and mpg-C3N4-x materials was analyzed by TG ( Fig. 3). The g-C3N4 had a very slight weight loss (ca. 3 %) within 500 °C, mainly due to the desorption of water or uncondensed nitrogen-containing small molecules. As the temperature was elevated, the TG curve of g-C3N4 showed a sharp weight loss; the residual weight obtained at 750 °C was nearly 0 %. This significant weight loss was attributed to the decomposition of CN functionalities in the C3N4 skeleton. Unlike g-C3N4 with relatively thermal stability within 500 °C, all the mpg-C3N4-x materials showed noticeable weight losses of ca. 10 % below 500 °C, suggesting that these materials should adsorb more water or other small molecules on their surface due to larger surface area than g-C3N4. The micro-morphology of the samples was observed by SEM ( Fig. 4). The SEM image of the g-C3N4 sample presented large agglomerated particles and stacked layered thick blocks whereas the image of mpg-C3N4-F revealed a large number of small particles. In the case of mpg-C3N4-0.3, the sample was also composed of small dispersed particles, despite some agglomerated particles. The SEM images of the mpg-C3N4-F and mpg-C3N4-0.3 materials agreed well with their higher surface areas than g-C3N4. Fig. 5 shows the TEM images of mpg-C3N4-F and mpg-C3N4-0.3. The image of mpg-C3N4-F presented worm-like porous structures with a pore size of ca. 12 nm, consistent with the results obtained in N2 adsorption–desorption (Table 1). The irregular mesoporous structures resulted from the etching of silica nanoparticles by NH4HF2 (a.q.). Like mpg-C3N4-F, mpg-C3N4-0.3 also had an irregular worm-like porous structure. However, a portion of pores exhibited aggregation or blockage. The chemical functional groups of different materials were analyzed by FT-IR ( Fig. 6). In the spectra of g-C3N4 and g-C3N4-0.3, the sharp bands at 808 cm−1 corresponded to the breathing mode of the conjugated heptazine units [25], and the multiple absorption bands at 17241157 cm−1 were assigned to the stretching vibration of the aromatic CN heterocycles [26]. The wide bands at 35042897 cm−1 were associated with the stretching vibrations of OH bonds of water molecules adsorbed on the surface of the g-C3N4 and NH bonds of amino species [27]. The FT-IR spectrum of the mpg-C3N4-F sample exhibited similar characteristic bands with g-C3N4, whereas the band intensity of 808 cm−1 was obviously weakened, indicative of a lower degree of intralayer stacking of graphitic structure. As noted above, the use of hard templates could introduce mesoporous structures in the final mpg-C3N4 sample. However, the etching procedure, especially under acidic NH4HF2 (a.q.) might sacrifice the alkaline nitrogen-containing species of mpg-C3N4 and even damage the condensation of heptazine units. Therefore, the intralayer stacking of graphitic structure acquired in mpg-C3N4-F was weakened compared with g-C3N4. By contrast, the bands of 808 cm−1 remained intensive in the spectra of the mpg-C3N4-x materials. Such a difference between mpg-C3N4-F and mpg-C3N4-x further implied that the treatment by NaOH (a.q.) could enhance the intralayer stacking of the graphitic structure of mpg-C3N4. Furthermore, the FT-IR spectrum of mpg-C3N4-SiO2 that had not been detemplated by NH4HF2 or NaOH was also recorded (Fig. S1). Compared with the FT-IR spectrum of g-C3N4, the unique bands appeared at 1109, 806, and 470 cm−1 in the spectrum of mpg-C3N4-SiO2, ascribed to the stretching, bending, and rocking vibrations of Si–O–Si bonds [28], respectively. In the spectra of mpg-C3N4-F and mpg-C3N4-0.3, the three characteristic bonds disappeared, confirming that the silica template in mpg-C3N4-SiO2 was removed by either NH4HF2 or NaOH solution. The electronic structures of g-C3N4 and mpg-C3N4-x materials were analyzed by UV-vis spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 7, all the materials had distinct absorption peaks in the UV region, corresponding to the band gap between HOMO and LUMO of the conjugated heptazine unit in the C3N4 material [29,30]. The g-C3N4 and g-C3N4-0.3 had very similar spectra; the mpg-C3N4-x materials exhibited pronounced absorption in the visible light region. Specifically, as the concentration of NaOH (a.q.) increased, the absorption intensity was improved in the cases of mpg-C3N4-x. This variation further suggested that the treatment of NaOH (a.q.) might alter the intralayer condensation of mpg-C3N4, therefore affecting the electronic structures thereof. The variation in absorption of visible light was also reflected in the apparent colors of these mesoporous materials. These mesoporous samples presented a dark yellow color while the g-C3N4 and g-C3N4-0.3 were light yellow. XPS technology was used further to analyze the surface chemical environment of the above materials. Fig. 8 shows the XPS full spectra of g-C3N4 and mpg-C3N4-x materials. Similar to g-C3N4, mpg-C3N4-x materials showed two intensive peaks at ca. 287 and 398 eV, attributed to the C and N elements respectively. In addition, the O element was detected in the XPS spectra, which came from the adsorbed water on the surface. It should be stressed that there were no signals associated with Si (Si 2p: 99–105 eV) detected in the spectra of the mesoporous samples, evidence of thorough removal of the silica template. The detailed chemical compositions of the materials were calculated and summarized in Table 2. Overall, the mpg-C3N4-x materials owned higher fractions of C than the g-C3N4 materials. For the preparation of mesoporous g-C3N4 via a hard-templating method, the silica nanoparticles were actually wrapped by the precursor (i.e. cyanamide). In this sense, the precursor phase was much thinner than the case without the templates (i.e. g-C3N4 and g-C3N4-0.3). Because nitrogen species were more liable to decompose during the calcination, the mpg-C3N4-x materials having thinner precursor phases would inevitably suffer from more decomposition of nitrogen-containing species than g-C3N4 materials. On the other hand, either g-C3N4-0.3 or mpg-C3N4-x possessed higher fractions of C than the corresponding materials that were not treated by NaOH (a.q.). This is due to the reaction between NaOH and some nitrogen-containing species of mpg-C3N4 (discussed below). As described above, the alkalinity of g-C3N4 materials was mainly derived from the nitrogen-containing functionalities. Compared with the conjugated nitrogen species in heptazine (hep) units (CN–C, Na) and the terminal amino groups (hep–NH2, Nc) at the edge of the graphite layer, the nitrogen atoms (hep–N(–hep)–hep, Nb) bridging heptazine rings were considered to be the most active alkaline sites [31,32] (Scheme S1). To analyze the distributions of these various nitrogen species, the high-resolution spectra of N 1 s of the materials were further deconvoluted ( Fig. 9). The N 1 s spectrum of each sample can be divided into three independent peaks. For g-C3N4, the major peak with a binding energy of 398.9 eV was attributed to the sp2 nitrogen atom (Na) in the heptazine unit, which accounted for the main proportion of the three nitrogen species. The peaks at 400.2 and 401.2 eV corresponded to the bridging nitrogen atoms (Nb) and the terminal amino group (Nc) at the end of the heptazine ring edges, respectively. Like that of g-C3N4, the N 1s spectra of mpg-C3N4-x materials were divided into three peaks, and the detailed percentages of N species are listed in Table 2. The percentages of Na, Nb, and Nc in mpg-C3N4-F were 68.2 %, 16.7 %, and 15.1 %, respectively. In the cases of mpg-C3N4-x materials, the fractions of Nc species were decreased while Nb species were increased remarkably. Obviously, this is attributed to the treatment of NaOH on mpg-C3N4. As reported by Su [21] and our group [12,20], alkaline solutions could react with the terminal amino groups located with adjacent heptazine units, transforming Nc to Nb species and releasing NH3 ( Scheme 1). Due to the linkage of the originally independent heptazine units, the intralayer stacking structure of g-C3N4 was consequently enhanced. Such a deprotonation effect on mpg-C3N4 by NaOH (a.q.) resulted in the increase in percentages of Nb species while a decline in the total nitrogen from mpg-C3N4-F to mpg-C3N4-x. Since the mpg-C3N4-0.3 had a higher fraction of Nb species, which were regarded as active alkaline sites with superior alkaline strength to Na species, we used the Hammett titration method adopting a series of indicators to test the alkalinity of the above materials. Table 3 summarizes the alkaline quantities based on different Hˍ values, i.e. alkaline strengths. According to the present analytic method, the pristine g-C3N4 and mpg-C3N4-F had no alkaline sites, or more accurately no stronger alkaline sites with an Hˍ higher than 7.4. On the contrary, g-C3N4-0.3 and mpg-C3N4-0.3 showed appreciable alkaline quantities in two strength ranges. Therein, it can be verified that the treatment by NaOH (a.q.) facilitated the formation of active alkaline sites on the two samples. Specifically, mpg-C3N4-0.3 possessed higher quantities than g-C3N4-0.3 in both weak and moderate alkaline strength, which was definitely attributed to its large surface area exposing more active alkaline sites. Besides Hammett titration, CO2-TPD technique was used to investigate the alkalinity of the materials. As described in Fig. 10, the profile of g-C3N4-0.3 presented a weak desorption and peak in the range of 80–190 °C, corresponding to physical adsorption of CO2. Due to their large surface areas, the mpg-C3N4-F, and mpg-C3N4-0.3 materials exhibited more intensive desorption peaks than g-C3N4-0.3. Specifically, the temperature of desorption peak gained in mpg-C3N4-0.3 was slightly higher than that of mpg-C3N4-F. Meanwhile, a minor peak emerged at ca. 255 °C in the case of mpg-C3N4-0.3, which could be attributed to weak alkaline sites. According to the CO2-TPD profiles, it can be revealed that mpg-C3N4-0.3 had higher alkaline strength than mpg-C3N4-F, in good agreement with the above Hammett-titration analytic results. It should be stressed that a small portion of the nitrogen-containing species (mainly oligomers) in C3N4 materials might still decompose under high desorption temperatures. The CO2-TPD baselines of both mpg-C3N4-F and mpg-C3N4-0.3 elevated as the desorption temperatures were higher than ca. 280 °C and such a phenomenon was discovered in some previously published work [17,19]. However,the phenomenon was not found in the case of g-C3N4-0.3. 3.2 Catalyst Evaluation As mentioned above, g-C3N4 and its related materials are typical solid bases. In general, the catalytic activity of g-C3N4 materials in heterogeneous catalysis is basically related to at least two factors. The first factor is the surface area and porous structures, and the other is the alkaline property (i.e. quantity and/or strength). The catalytic performances of g-C3N4 materials were evaluated in the transesterification reactions between EC and CH3OH with a reaction temperature of 140 °C and reaction time of 2 h. The yield of DMC in a blank experiment without any catalysts was only 13.9 % ( Table 4). After g-C3N4 of 100 mg was added to the reaction system, the conversion of EC was slightly increased to 21.4 %. Although g-C3N4 was a solid base material, the catalytic activity in the reaction was limited mainly due to its low surface area (Table 1). Using the g-C3N4-0.3 material treated with NaOH instead, the EC conversion was significantly increased to 63.6 %. This is because the treatment led to deprotonation of g-C3N4, enhancing the active Nb species (Table 2) and eventual basic quantity (Table 3). On the other hand, the mpg-C3N4-F material prepared by the hard-templating approach showed higher activity than g-C3N4 but lower than g-C3N4-0.3 under identical reaction conditions. As listed in Table 2, g-C3N4 and g-C3N4-0.3 owned superior Nb percentages to mpg-C3N4-F. Notwithstanding, the two materials were prepared via a simple calcination method, without using hard templates like mpg-C3N4. The surface areas were 11 and 9 m2·g−1, respectively, whereas the surface area of mpg-C3N4-F was up to 216 m2·g−1 (Table 1). The mesoporous structures of mpg-C3N4-F were really able to expose more active alkaline sites, while the acidic etching agent (NH4HF2, a.q.) would neutralize part of the alkaline sites, thereby restricting substantial improvement of catalytic activity from g-C3N4 to mpg-C3N4-F. The mpg-C3N4-x materials that were detemplated by NaOH (a.q.) showed remarkably high catalytic activity. For mpg-C3N4-0.2 material with a low concentration of NaOH, the conversion of EC obtained was 75.9 %, and the conversion EC reached up to 81.2 % in the case of mpg-C3N4-0.3. However, adopting mpg-C3N4 with a higher concentration of NaOH, the conversions dropped. This should be due to the collapse of mesostructures of mpg-C3N4 under a higher concentration of NaOH solution, as reflected in the variation of surface areas in Table 1. Based on the catalytic results, it can be inferred that, for g-C3N4 materials in this study, alkaline strength played a more important role in enhancing the catalytic activity than high surface area. The bridging Nb species has the highest alkaline strength among the three types of nitrogen species in the heptazine-based C3N4 framework. To further study the effect of bridging Nb species of C3N4 materials on their catalytic activity, the EC conversions were plotted against the percentages of Nb species. As depicted in Fig. 11, the conversions correlated well with the fractions of Nb species of the materials. In the cases of mpg-C3N4-x materials, mpg-C3N4-0.3 possessed the largest percentage of Nb species (24.1 %) along with the highest EC conversion (81.2 %). Therefore, it can be further speculated that the Nb species played a crucial catalytic role in transesterification reactions. Using mpg-C3N4-0.3 as a representative catalyst, we investigated the influences of reaction temperature and time on the catalytic performance. As shown in Fig. 12A, the EC conversion was only 46.3 % at the reaction temperature of 110 °C. With the elevated reaction temperatures, the conversion increased progressively. As the temperature exceeded 140 °C, the conversion of EC tended to be stable. The catalytic performance of the catalyst was also sensitive to the reaction time. As the reaction was prolonged (Fig. 12B), the conversion of EC increased rapidly within 1 h whereas smoothly from 76 % to 83 % in the following 1.5 h. Based on the two trends, a reaction temperature of 140 °C and reaction time of 2 h were adopted as optimal reaction conditions for further study. Besides EC and CH3OH, the catalytic performance of mpg-C3N4-0.3 material was further investigated by using propylene carbonate (PC) and C2H5OH as substrates ( Table 5). Under the same reaction conditions, the conversion of PC (31.7 %) was much lower than in the case of EC (81.2 %). This was because the carbonyl carbon atoms in PC were less active than those of EC. Nevertheless, the conversion of PC could be improved when a higher reaction temperature was adopted. On the other hand, although the OH bond in C2H5OH was more difficult to dissociate than CH3OH, in the transesterification reaction between EC and C2H5OH, the conversion of EC was also as high as 76.5 %. The above tests proved that the mpg-C3N4-0.3 catalyst can be applied for transesterification reactions with wide cyclic carbonates and lower alcohols. In addition to catalytic activity and selectivity, recyclability, and reproductivity of catalysts are also important aspects of examining the performance of heterogeneous catalysts. Herein, we carried out recycling experiments by using mpg-C3N4-0.3 as a representative catalyst. As shown in Fig. 13, the conversion of EC dropped from 81.2 % to 71.7 % during the first cycle, while the selectivity of DMC was consistently close to 100 %. The slight decrease in catalytic activity may be due to the partial loss of the catalyst solid during the recycling process. Within the subsequent four runs, the conversions of EC were maintained at ca. 70 %, indicating that the catalyst as a heterogeneous catalyst had steady recyclability. The recycled catalyst was analyzed by N2 adsorptiondesorption (Fig. S2), FT-IR ( Fig. 14A), and XRD (Fig. 14B) techniques. The characterization results verified that the mesoporous structure as well as the large surface area (Table S1) of the recycled catalyst was preserved, and the crystallinity and chemical functional groups of the catalyst did not alter significantly after four consecutive cycles compared with the fresh one. Moreover, the total chemical composition of the recycled mpg-C3N4-0.3 calculated based on the XPS survey was C0.858N1O0.097 (Table 2), very close to the value of the fresh catalyst (C0.856N1O0.075). The N 1 s spectrum of the recycled catalyst was also deconvoluted ( Fig. 15) and compared with that of the fresh one. The distributions of various nitrogen species showed no apparent changes, responsible for the relatively stable recycling catalysis of the mpg-C3N4-0.3 material. 3.3 Possible catalytic mechanism To further elucidate the catalytic activity of mpg-C3N4-F and mpg-C3N4-0.3 in the transesterification reactions, we conducted a control experiment by FT-IR. Fig. 16A shows the spectra of the two samples before contact with CH3OH. As described above, the two spectra demonstrated identical three transmittance regions. After the pellet was contacted with CH3OH (The methanol liquid was firstly dropped onto the pellet, followed by evaporation of methanol until the pellet was dry.), besides the original characteristic bands associated with g-C3N4, multiple bands emerged at ca. 1055 cm−1 (Fig. 16B), indexed as vibrations of C−O bond of CH3OH [33]. For mpg-C3N4-F, an intensive band appeared at 3588 cm−1, indexed as O−H bonds [34,35] like in the spectrum of CH3OH. However, the band was not detected in the spectrum of mpg-C3N4-0.3. Actually, the transmittance between 3500 and 3000 cm−1 of mpg-C3N4-0.3 showed no obvious changes after the contact with CH3OH. That is, according to this control experiment, it was observed that the O−H bonds of CH3OH molecules had been dissociated in mpg-C3N4-0.3 while still existed in mpg-C3N4-F. As revealed in the analytic results of XPS, the difference in this behavior was attributed to the active alkaline sites in mpg-C3N4-0.3. According to the above FT-IR analytic results and relevant literature [10,15,36] involving transesterification catalyzed by carbon nitride materials, a possible catalytic pathway was proposed ( Scheme 2). First, a molecule of CH3OH was adsorbed and then activated by alkaline nitrogen atoms of mpg-C3N4 (Step I, hep is the abbreviation of heptazine), generating methoxide anion (CH3O−) and conjugate acid (NH+) on mpg-C3N4. Afterwards, the CH3O− as a nucleophile attacked the sp2-hybridized carbon atom (CO), resulting in the ring opening of the EC and then transformation into an alkoxide anion (Step II). The alkoxide anion reacted with another molecule of CH3OH by proton exchange, thus transforming CH3O− and 2-hydroxyethyl methyl carbonate (HEMC) as an intermediate (Step III). Subsequently, the as-generated CH3O− nucleophilically attacked HEMC (Step IV), followed by the formation of DMC and EG anion. Finally, the EG anion reacted with the abovementioned conjugate acid (NH+) on mpg-C3N4 and transformed to EG (Step V). Meanwhile, the alkaline nitrogen atoms of mpg-C3N4 were restored. Based on this possible pathway, due to the deprotonation by NaOH (a.q.), the mpg-C3N4-x materials possessed higher fractions of alkaline nitrogen species than mpg-C3N4-F, therefore demonstrating superior catalytic activity in the transesterification reaction. 3.4 Catalytic comparison As mentioned above, C3N4-based materials have been applied as solid bases to catalyze a number of base-mediated organic reactions. With regard to catalytic transesterification of cyclic carbonates catalyzed by C3N4, there are several examples reported recently. Herein, for the sake of catalyst comparison, a series of relevant catalyst examples have been surveyed and included in Table 6. The information covers the detailed reaction conditions and catalytic productivity (catal. prod.) of DMC. As listed in Table 6, the highest productivity of DMC was achieved in the K-O2/NMC catalyst (61.2 gDMC·gcatal −1·h−1), which could be even operated under a low reaction temperature. However, the active component of the catalyst was exactly K+. Such strong alkaline species were easy to absorb acidic CO2, leading to slow deactivation of the catalyst [37]. In addition, the metal ion was prone to leach into the liquid-phase reaction system. Also, the CN-SiAlO and Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4 catalysts previously reported by our group contained metal cations, thus facing the potential metal contamination of the catalytic products. As for the metal-free catalysts, i.e. eg-C3N4-NH3, NOMC-1.6D, and C3N4-500, the present mpg-C3N4-0.3 catalyst shows moderate catalytic productivity (9.1 gDMC·gcatal −1·h−1). Combining its eco-friendly preparation procedure and good recyclability, the mesostructured carbon nitride catalyst could be utilized as a metal-free solid base for wide catalytic reactions. 4 Conclusion In summary, a series of mpg-C3N4 materials with large surface areas (97–116 m2·g−1) were successfully prepared by the hard-templating method. The use of NaOH (a.q.) could not only effectively remove the silica template but also enhance the alkaline strength of mpg-C3N4 by improving the percentage of bridging nitrogen species. The treatment of NaOH also improved the degree of intralayer stacking of mpg-C3N4, depending on the concentration of NaOH (a.q.). In the transesterification of EC with CH3OH, the mpg-C3N4-x materials as metal-free heterogeneous catalysts demonstrated superior catalytic activity to mpg-C3N4-F prepared using NH4HF2 (a.q.) as the etching agent, affording maximum yield of DMC of 81.2 % at 2 h under 140 °C. Additionally, the catalysts showed good stability and catalytic versatility. Owing to its metal-free advantage together with high catalytic activity, it is anticipated that the mpg-C3N4 could be a choice for a more sustainable heterogeneous catalyst for the clean synthesis of DMC and wide transesterification reactions. coredata.dc:description: Dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is an important building block in modern chemical synthesis, and the transesterification reaction between ethylene carbonate (EC) and CH3OH has been widely regarded as one of the most promising routes for the synthesis of DMC. Herein, a series of mesoporous carbon nitride (mpg-C3N4-x) materials were synthesized through a hard-templating method, adopting NaOH (a.q.) as a facile detemplating agent. Compared with the mpg-C3N4-F material prepared using traditional corrosive NH4HF2 (a.q.) as the detemplating agent, the mpg-C3N4-x materials possessed higher percentages of active bridging nitrogen species. Under optimal reaction conditions, the conversion of EC and selectivity to DMC achieved in mpg-C3N4 were up to 81.2 % and 99.9 %. The utilization of NaOH (a.q.) could alter the distributions of nitrogen species and enhance the alkaline strength of mpg-C3N4. As metal-free heterogeneous catalysts, the mpg-C3N4-x materials showed good recyclability and versatility for the transesterification reactions of various substrates.
